Abstract: We present a novel deep‑learning architecture that predicts quantum‑chemical properties with unprecedented accuracy. Methods: Our model employs a graph‑neural‑network encoder combined with a transformer‑based decoder to learn molecular representations directly from SMILES strings. Training was performed on the QM9 dataset (133,885 molecules) using a mean‑squared‑error loss on atomization energies, dipole moments, and polarizabilities. Results: The proposed method achieves a mean absolute error of 0.12 kcal/mol on atomization energies, improving by 15 % over the previous state‑of‑the‑art. It also reduces error on dipole moments by 10 % and on polarizabilities by 12 %. Conclusion: This work demonstrates that end‑to‑end deep learning can reliably predict a wide range of quantum‑chemical properties, opening pathways for rapid virtual screening in materials discovery.

messages.content:
Deep Learning for Quantum Chemistry:

Recent advances in deep‑learning have enabled accurate prediction of quantum‑chemical properties directly from molecular structures. A novel architecture that couples a graph‑neural‑network encoder with a transformer‑based decoder was trained on the QM9 dataset, achieving a mean absolute error of 0.12 kcal/mol for atomization energies—an improvement of 15 % over prior methods—and notable reductions in error for dipole moments (10 %) and polarizabilities (12 %). These results illustrate the potential of end‑to‑end deep‑learning pipelines to accelerate materials discovery through rapid virtual screening.

Author, A., Author, B., & Author, C. (2025). Deep Learning for Quantum Chemistry. Unpublished manuscript.
